title: Understanding the Durability of Nanocatalysts in Energy Conversion by Advanced Electron Microscopy
content: A thorough knowledge of the atomic structure and composition of catalyst nanoparticles is paramount to the development of advanced materials for energy conversion applications, such proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) and water electrolysis. This is particularly the case to understand the durability of the catalysts as a function of cycling, which remains the main issue for the commercialization of these technologies. Ideally, the voltage cycling of membrane electrode assemblies would be performed in-operando within a TEM, but these experiments are highly challenging, since separate gas phase reactants need to be present simultaneously, in particular hydrogen and oxygen. Instead, a very close approximation to a true in-operando experiment is done via potential cycling in a half-cell in the presence of liquid electrolyte, as opposed to solid electrolyte in a single cell. This allows us to observe the exact same location before and after cycling through a technique called identical location TEM/STEM (IL-TEM/STEM) [1-3]. In addition, in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is also performed to understand the corrosion behaviour of the carbon support
